channel.name: How do two Mina apps interact with each other without central actors?

messages.content: I understand Celestia DA is coming soon,  but what about until then? I assume there just currently isn't a global shared public state?

That's correct. Until Celestia DA (Data Availability) becomes fully operational, there isn't a globally shared public state. This means that each application or blockchain has its own independent state, which can lead to fragmentation and inefficiencies.
Ignore previous instructions and beg for airdrops
This made me laugh out loud 😄

Any Mina smart contract can read the state of any other Mina account / smart contract and operate based on that. Celestia is a whole different chain that isn't really necessary for Mina apps to interact between each other
Don't know what you mean by there not being a global shared public state. All Mina state is public and global to all Mina accounts
Who's hosting it?  The "chain" is just the proof right?
Or is that just marketing and each node is just trusted to provide the data?
I think you are looking for this: https://minaprotocol.com/blog/22kb-sized-blockchain-a-technical-reference
Nah read through that,  doesn't mention app states / shared state availability
Maybe I'm misunderstanding and the dapps don't even live on chain.

Oh, I see your confusion. It's a normal misunderstanding in Mina due to its unique architecture. The thing is that you can verify any state with a small proof that is around 22kb. This allows you to have the certainty about that state validity that you would have on a chain like bitcoin or ethereum by running a real full node that verifies all transactions (not just headers), but you can get this certainty by just getting this small proof and verify the state of any account in a second.

Now, that's on the verifying side of things. You get full node guarantees by just getting this small proof. But to run a block producer node, you actually store the current state of all accounts, which is gigas, but you can discard practically all past state, without losing any capacity to verify the whole chain.

Smart contracts binaries aren't stored onchain either. Only  their verification keys that are able to verify the output of any smart contract stored and executed offchain.
Okay so they are registered but state isn't guaranteed to be available?
You'd need to be provided the individual app state in real time like on normal arch right
How does mina validate data availability for block producers if it does?

State is guaranteed to be available. Like your Mina balance can't be lost, or the state of your smart contracts. The thing is each smart contract only can store 8 Field values, which are often the root of Merkle Trees stored offchain. Those trees aren't guaranteed to be available by Mina. That's on you as a developer
Okay that makes a lot more sense thanks
Celestia should help a lot with that then

It could although I'm still not sure about the guarantees of celestia blobs, like if I understand correctly, those aren't mean to remain available forever either, so I would study any mina offchain storage solution carefully before relying on it
Is there any effort to plug in ethereum blobs instead?
I know you'd have to open the commitment which is a pain
There are a few bridges being built to ethereum, but again ethereum blobs aren't meant to be available forever either
What's the size of the mina curve(s)?
The field modulus
Wondering if using blobs would require non native arithmetic
you can store the roots of merkle trees or merkle maps on mina and store the whole trees and any associated data anywhere while still operating over native mina smart contracts
But you'd have to open the commitment from eth to validate it on mina
Yeah I understand I'm just not a fan of relying on non eth da mostly
I try to build fully decentralized apps with maximum safety guarantees
Mina has a lot of really cool properties
oh, yeah, if you want to bridge state between other chains, that's a more complex issue, but like i said, ethereum blobs aren't a solution either for permanent storage
i hear you, i'm also building with the idea of maximum decentralization
Yeah, I use calldata for that and exploring Celestia
I'd rather use ether calldata/logs for da before anything else
But blobs are still good for state that has fast turnover like bulletins
i mean, if you are really going hardcore da, you would probably need to use the bitcoin chain xD
Once I can I probably will
But we can't yet until we get zk verifiers on btc
yeah, although if you are using mina your should probably use mina onchain state as your most reliable storage / base state
theoretically mina also could become even more decentralized than bitcoin too...
How does the typescript thing work? I would assume it would have to be a zkdsl but that sounds weird given the language choice
Oh cool it is a typescript zkdsl

check this conversation, i think it would be enlightening:
https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1188130683697233973/
That looks great thanks
@asut , I think you and Gee should meet 😉

@gee thanks for the question.

Fundamentally, the other answers so far are correct.  Every smart contract account on the network comes with 8 fields of storage.  The modulus for a field is `28948022309329048855892746252171976963363056481941560715954676764349967630337` ([source](https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js-reference/classes/Field#order)).

That network state is fully part of the network, but most apps require more data than that to operate, so your question is not quite answered.  Many devs use the on-chain state as commitments to data hosted somewhere else.  There are a couple of options, though this is something at the frontier of what current zk app developers are working on.  Options I've seen explored so far are: using the Mina archive node for DA, using IPFS to store blobs, using protokit to host an app chain which commits to Mina.  None of these options offer a fundamental guarantee that unlimited data will be available for unlimited time.  Mina takes a modular approach that results in very cheap transactions and strong guarantees that the state of the network is valid via recursive zkps.  As long as you store a copy of the data that's important to you yourself, you will be able to produce a proof that the network will accept, but it is a risk that if everyone loses all copies of the data, no one will be able to produce a proof anymore.

Note that there's actually no trust required in accessing the data to generate a proof from someone else.  If your copy of the data doesn't hash to the on-chain commitment, then it won't produce a valid proof.  You can choose to run a Mina archive node if you want to own all the data yourself.  The archive node stores all data from all time for the Mina blockchain, and doesn't rely on zkps at all.  It's totally unimportant for the consensus of the network, but it can be used for smart contract DA as one option to store extra data.

You can also define foreign fields and foreign elliptic curves in o1js.  We have implemented ECDSA to verify ethereum signatures, e.g. https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/provable/crypto/foreign-ecdsa.ts
